[[Lynchburg, Tennessee|Lynchburg]], [[Tennessee]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|2002|7|27|1931|8|22|mf=y}}
[[Nashville, Tennessee]], United States | origin = | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]] | genre = [[Electric blues]], [[Louisiana blues]], [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]] | years_active = 1949–2002 | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Roscoe Shelton''' (August 22, 1931 – July 27, 2002) was an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] and [[rhythm and blues|R&B]] [[singing|singer]].{{cite web|author=Joe Viglione |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/roscoe-shelton-mn0000342226/biography |title=Roscoe Shelton | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} He is best remembered for his 1965 [[hit single]], "Strain on My Heart," and his working relationships with both [[The Fairfield Four]] and [[Bobby Hebb]]. Other notable recordings include "Think It Over" and "Baby Look What You're Doin' To Me".{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2002b.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 2002 July to December |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} Fred James, who [[record producer|produced]] much of Shelton's later work, noted that Shelton moved effortlessly into [[soul music|soul]], unlike many of his 1950s blues and R&B recording contemporaries. ==Biography== Shelton was born in [[Lynchburg, Tennessee]] and was raised in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://www.mnblues.com/profile/gaines-shelton-pf99.html |title=Roscoe Shelton - Blues Profile|author=Stiles, Ray |publisher=Mnblues.com |accessdate=March 23, 2010}}{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/2002-08-22/stories/rosco-gordon-roscoe-shelton-1931-2002/|title=Roscoe Shelton (1931-2002) - Further evidence that an era has ended|author=Wynn, Ron |publisher=Nashvillescene.com |accessdate=March 23, 2010}} In 1949 he joined the Fairfield Four, singing lead vocals on their [[gospel music]] output, before spending four years [[conscription|conscripted]] in the [[United States Air Force]]. Upon discharge he joined The Skylarks in 1956 and [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] for [[Excello Records|Excello's]] subsidiary [[record label|label]], Nashboro Records. After the group disbanded Shelton sang alongside and toured with both [[Bobby Hebb]] and DeFord Bailey, Jr. In 1961 Shelton's debut [[album]] ''Roscoe Shelton Sings'' was released by Excello, before various [[single (music)|singles]] followed, including "Strain on My Heart" (1965). The track was a [[Top 40]] success in the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]]. By this time Shelton's work appeared on [[Sound Stage 7]], and another Top 40 hit was "Easy Going Fellow." In 1966 his next album ''Soul in His Music, Music in His Soul'' was released, but the long gap between albums stalled his career. However, Shelton performed on the same bill as [[Otis Redding]] at the [[Apollo Theater]]. The deaths of both Redding and [[Sam Cooke]], who had been friends of Shelton, took their toll. Shelton left the [[music industry]] in 1969, working for Nashville's [[Meharry Medical College]]. Finally in 1994 Shelton, [[Earl Gaines]], and [[Clifford Curry]] found work billed as the 'Excello Legends'. In 1995, Shelton's song "You Were the Dream" appeared on the [[soundtrack]] of the [[film]], ''[[Blue Juice]]''. His recording resumed under the production of Fred James, spawning amongst others, ''Let It Shine'' in 1998, plus Shelton's and Gaines' joint effort, ''Let's Work Together''. In July 2002, at the age of 70, Shelton died of [[cancer]] in Nashville.{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://www.bluenight.com/BluesBytes/wn0507.html|title=Roscoe Shelton|author=Shutro, Alan |publisher=Bluenight.com |accessdate=March 23, 2010}} Two years after his death, Shelton's "Say You Really Care" was included on the [[Grammy Award]] winning [[compilation album]], ''[[Night Train to Nashville]].'' ==Discography== ===Albums=== *''Roscoe Shelton Sings'' ([[Excello Records|Excello]], 1961) *''Soul in His Music, Music in His Soul'' ([[Sound Stage 7]], 1966) *''Strain on Your Heart'' ([[Charly Records|Charly]], 1987) *''Roscoe Shelton Sings'' ([[P-Vine Records|P-Vine]], 1995) *''She's the One'' (Appaloosa, 1996) *''Tennessee R&B Live'' (Appaloosa, 1997) *''Let It Shine'' ([[Black Top Records|Black Top]], 1998) *''Let's Work Together'' (Cannonball, 2000){{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/roscoe-shelton-mn0000342226/discography |title=Roscoe Shelton | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} ===Singles=== *"I've Been Faithful" / "We've Been Wrong" (1960) (Excello 2146) *"Strain on My Heart" (1965) - [[United States|US]] [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B Singles]] no. 25 *"Easy Going Fellow" (1966) - US R&B Singles no. 32{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/roscoe-shelton-mn0000342226/awards |title=Roscoe Shelton | Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} ==See also== *[[List of electric blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.soulwalking.co.uk/Roscoe%20Shelton.html Soulwalking.co.uk] *[http://jazztimes.com/articles/12046-let-s-work-together-earl-gaines-roscoe-shelton Review of ''Let's Work Together''] {{Authority control|VIAF=19290707}} {{Persondata | NAME = Shelton, Roscoe | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] and [[rhythm and blues|R&B]] singer | DATE OF BIRTH = August 22, 1931 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Lynchburg, Tennessee]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = July 27, 2002 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Shelton, Roscoe}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:American rhythm and blues singers]] [[Category:Cancer deaths in Tennessee]] [[Category:Electric blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Tennessee]]
